149821163.review:
Little Misfortune had the potential to be a charming and whimsical adventure, but it ultimately left me feeling unsatisfied and frustrated. Here's why:

Firstly, the narrative, while initially intriguing, quickly devolves into a series of dark and unsettling themes without much depth or nuance. The attempts at humor often fall flat, and the overall tone feels inconsistent, making it difficult to connect with the protagonist, Misfortune.

The gameplay mechanics are simplistic to a fault. The choices you make seem to have minimal impact on the story, rendering the decision-making process more of a formality than a meaningful engagement. The lack of consequence for your actions diminishes any sense of agency, leaving the player feeling like a passive observer rather than an active participant.

The puzzles in the game are disappointingly easy, offering little challenge for players seeking a more engaging experience. The lack of variety and complexity in the gameplay makes Little Misfortune feel like a missed opportunity to provide a more stimulating and rewarding adventure.

Furthermore, the game's relatively short duration leaves you wanting more, but not in a positive way. It feels like the narrative is cut short, leaving loose ends and unanswered questions. Instead of a satisfying conclusion, you're left with a sense of confusion and a lack of closure.

While the art style and music contribute to the game's atmosphere, they can't compensate for the overall lackluster storytelling and gameplay. Little Misfortune falls short of delivering a truly memorable and enjoyable experience, making it a regrettable addition to your gaming library. Save your time and explore other titles that offer a more fulfilling adventure.

149598017.review:
Este juego tiene el mismo tipo de ambientación que el [i]Fran Bow[/i], pero con una historia totalmente nueva.
Todo comienza con una voz dirigiéndose a nosotros, el cual nos presenta a la protagonista, una niña muy mona. La niña también es capaz de oír esta voz y, tras un diálogo, deciden jugar a un juego, donde la niña conseguirá la [b]Felicidad Eterna[/b]. Así, al lado de esta voz y de la niña, viviremos una aventura donde tendremos que tomar decisiones, y todas estas decisiones tienen consecuencias.

Lo [b]importante[/b] de este juego es la manera que tiene de contarnos la realidad, ya que contamos con dos tipos de perspectivas: el jugador(nosotros), siendo esta más adulta, y la de la niña, siendo más infantil. Realmente ocurren cosas muy chocantes y [b]muy, pero muy reales[/b]. Desde la terrible situación familiar, como presenciar muertes, adicciones o cómo los habitantes se ocultan detrás de máscaras. Pero, aunque tenga [b]temas muy importantes[/b], nuestro camino sigue adelante como si nada. La protagonista lanza purpurina a todo lo que sea malo y ya estaría todo solucionado.

Visualmente está genial, tiene buenas animaciones y muchos detalles, donde la música acompaña bien a todo esto.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
El juego es una aventura con una gran crítica a la realidad y con temas de humor también. Aunque el juego dure muy poco (yo me lo pasé en 3h), lo recomiendo comprar pero en rebajas, merece muchísimo la pena ♡

149138248.review:
TL;DR: Worth to play at least once, but the story can't deliver as strongly as expected.

Having played and enjoyed Fran Bow, I had this game in my radar as well, the trailer seemed very promising. Needless to say, having completed every possible choice in the game and completed it 100%, I have to give it a negative review.

Don't get me wrong, I knew the gameplay would be minimal, after all it IS a point and click game. But the story was lacking...something stronger. The beginning was really great and as the story progressed it was nice to have this mystery as to what was going to happen. But after maybe 1/3 of the game, it became not only predictable, but also quite dull. There was no plot twist, no change of pace, I even expected the villain to be even scarier. It was definitely a disappointment. Nevertheless, I would recommend playing at least one run of the game, since it has some nice moments and fun things to try. 

PS: Since it is a game that needs multiple runs for the achievements, it would be better to have a bit faster skipping dialogue option. It has a basic cutscene skip and a basic "click to skip half a line", but it takes a bit of time to redo some of the game scenes.

148041240.review:
This game is important to me. It's a tale about a girl named Misfortune who heads out on a search for Eternal Happiness. The game is quirky and bizarre. The art style is magnificent. The music is phenomenal. I listen to Music 4 Ever, an original tune from this game, years after having finished it for the first time. Unlike Fran Bow, this game is way more accessible, as it's purely narrative-focused, with no puzzles so to speak. The game has a unique allure, the vibrant graphics mixed with a macabre undertone make for a hunting vibe that persisted long after the final credits.

The reviewers don't get it in my opinion. This is a fascinating tale, one to remember, but not so simple to grasp the genius within. You see during the game, Misfortune can throw magic sparks that make the world a more loving space. If you manage to throw your positivity and childhood naivete on every possible instance, you do find Eternal Happiness. [spoiler] By your dying, you give happiness to your mother. [/spoiler] I'll add my take on this ending sometime later but bear with me, this ending has such significance for me, I've even got an original tattoo of Benjamin, the well-spirited fox Misfortune adores. Simply on my top 10 list.

Pero los dos juegos ofrecen algo muy diferente. Fran Bow es una aventura gráfica muy profunda e interesante, mientras que Little Misfortune es más bien una novela visual de corta duración. Siento que si hubiese jugado este juego esperando eso lo habría podido disfrutar más. Tiene una protagonista carismática y un trasfondo de crítica social que es interesante, y la experiencia en sí es buena, pero al final mucho de lo que lo hace interesante simplemente es una pequeña muestra del mundo que ya creó Fran Bow. 147580983.review:
My wife and I played this as a short and simple lighthearted horror game, and I think it was overall enjoyable. The artwork was really nice, and the voice acting was pretty decent. It's a very short game (a single playthrough takes ~2.5 hours), and it's a nice self-contained story. I thought the story was enjoyable, though I wish the decisions you made throughout the game actually had an impact on the plot (they just change what dialog/activity happens immediately after the decision, but then you're back on the exact same track regardless of your choice). I also wasn't a huge fan of all the poop/fart/vomit jokes: I'm sure the goal was to make it seem innocent/childish (the setting of the game is that you're seeing these dark things from the eyes of an innocent child), but they were a bit unnecessary and didn't really add to the feeling of the game, but actually took away in my opinion.

Overall, this is definitely not worth $20 in my opinion, but if it's on a steep sale, it's an enjoyable short game for a spooky season evening

I've played this game 3 times, but only now got to the review. 
There are no word to describe this game. it's dark, it's whimsical, it is tragic and both makes your heart grow.

Little misfortune is a very emotional interactive story about a child (Little Misfortune) who comes from a broken family and touches on issues very relevant to our society such as child abuse/neglect, a broken family, drug abuse, child exploitation, suicide, prostitution, the afterlife. 

The game's mechanics allow you to explore the world and interact with objects and characters while making decisions that impact the story's progression. The standout feature is Misfortune's ability to throw glitter, symbolizing her resilience and ability to find light in darkness.

In the end, Little Misfortune is a rollercoaster ride through darkness and innocence, propelled by memorable characters and a heartfelt message of resilience. It's an imperfect but compelling experience that leaves players with a sense of both discomfort and wonder in the intricacies of life

I can't wait for killmonday to release more games.
This one goes to one of my top games of all time.

I see some similarities with other games such as Red Candle Games' Detention and Devotion and Playdead's Limbo in the sense that the characters are trying to find closure.

Me costó decidirme si recomendar este juego o no, pero después de mucho pensar me decidí a que no vale la pena comprar este juego.

Yo soy bastante fan de este tipo de juegos, de echo tengo Fran Bow ( un juego de los mismo productores y que se lleva a cabo en el mismo universo que Little Misfortune) y lo adoro con toda mi alma.
Pero Little Misfortune a sido una completa decepción a mis expectativas. Lo más probable es que sea por el echo de que esperaba un juego con las mismas mecanicas que Fran Bow, osea un point and click con puzzles y minijuegos. 
pero creo incluso que sin mis expectativas, este juego habría consiguido decepcionarme igualmente, y es que más que un juego, es una especie de pelicula interactiva., ya que no tiene minijuegos, distintos finales, ni mucho menos te hacen tomar desciones relevantes para el juego, es un juego corto sin ningun tipo de mecanica especial aparte de caminar hacia adelante.

Eso sí, no todo es malo, el juego en si, osea, lo que es jugar, es tremendamente tedioso y decepcionante.
Pero el arte y la narración son esplendidos, admito además que uno de mis juegos favoritos es The Stanley Parable, y Mr.Voice es el mismo actor que The Narrator,  por lo que el toque que le ha dado al juego es fantastico.
Otro punto que me gusto del juego fueron las referencias a Fran Bow, como por ejemplo lo de los cinco reinos, las piñas o, personalmente mi favorita, Inward.

En conclusión: Si eres fan de Fran Bow y comprandote este juego esperas tener y una experiencia parecida, NO lo compres. si te gustan los juegos donde tus decisiones afectan el final del juego, No lo compres.
si te gustan los cortos interactivos y con un narrador esplendido y un arte exepcional, Felicidades! este juego es para ti.

145705353.review:
[h1] Little Misfortune: Glitter Thrown Amidst Darkness [/h1]

"Little Misfortune" is a whimsical yet dark fairytale horror game developed by Killmonday Games. It tells the story of Misfortune Ramirez Hernandez, a young girl surrounded by tragedy, who embarks on an interactive adventure at the whims of a mysterious voice named Mr. Voice. This voice offers her eternal happiness in exchange for playing a game, a chance she gladly seizes.

The game's mechanics allow you to explore the world and interact with objects and characters while making decisions that impact the story's progression. The standout feature is Misfortune's ability to throw glitter, symbolizing her resilience and ability to find light in darkness.

Misfortune's character is endearing, and her ability to use glitter as a metaphor for perseverance and appreciating the little things is charming.

However, the game struggles with balancing its dark themes and juvenile humor. It delves into real-world horrors, including abuse and suicide, but sometimes these elements feel like they're included for shock value rather than contributing to the narrative. The tonal mismatch between these serious themes and humor can be jarring.

Despite these challenges, the game's short runtime and focused narrative make choices feel meaningful, even if they don't drastically alter the plot. The love for Misfortune and the desire to outsmart Mr. Voice serve as compelling motivations.

While some repetitive voice lines and odd dialogue choices exist, the game's moments of rebellion against Mr. Voice provide a sense of satisfaction and delight. Despite the darkness that envelops her, Misfortune's resilience and optimism shine through, making "Little Misfortune" a unique and engaging experience.

In the end, Little Misfortune is a rollercoaster ride through darkness and innocence, propelled by memorable characters and a heartfelt message of resilience. It's an imperfect but compelling experience that leaves players with a sense of both discomfort and wonder in the intricacies of life, the streuggles within them and the mystique of death.

145687675.review:
I feel conflicted about this title. The primary reason for this is that I adore the team's prior game, Fran Bow, and thus I went in wanting more of the same. However, while Little Misfortune doesn’t stray from the art style and tone of the team's first commercial release it does cut out the point-and-click puzzle gameplay which for me is disappointing.

You can clearly see a greater emphasis on polished and improved artwork, at least from a technical perspective, within the game in contrast to their prior game. The title has a “hand drawn” photoshop look that is charming and lovely. It’s wonderful that the developers are improving their craft overtime. With that said, I think there was a decent amount of charm loss despite technical improvement. The world and environments are simply more stale. The areas you explore feel small, less creative, and less inspired. This likely is tied to the fact that the main character is locked to either walking left or right, completely locked in a 2D plane, which completely undermines any sense of exploration within the world.

The game feels self indulgence, giving the developer an excuse to paint, animate, and design all day, which is clearly what they love to do. However, it comes at the cost of them not putting their players first. It’s like the gameplay developers just left and all that remained were the artists. There needs to be a balance between interesting gameplay elements and lovely artwork. Sadly, this one leans way too far in the artwork direction. It feels like this would just have been better as an animated short but I’m not sure that would have been as profitable.

I don’t recommend Little Misfortune unfortunately. Without the comparison to their prior title, I might have found it okay, but the reality is I wanted more of what Killmonday Games initially created as it was stellar. However, I’m hopeful that the studio will continue to produce great games. This one is cute, has wonderful art, but lacks soul and only contains the tiniest shred of interactivity required to pass as a game which killed it for me.

What can I say, this game is faaaaaaaancayyyyyyyy

This dark and surreal adventure is pretty short, but extremely entertaining! 
Little Misfortune is less a puzzle game, and more of a walking sim that tells the story of an especially unfortunate little girl who follows the directions of an unknown voice through a quest to find "eternal happiness".

The wonderful art, story, and voice acting carry this game as an interesting and often spooky story telling experience with plenty of mysteries to unravel. 

Just a warning, there is a HEAVY use of dark humor throughout this game that I can see turning off certain people. Seriously, this game does NOT pull any punches. Do not play if you don't enjoy laughing at REAL messed up stuff.

If you are still on the fence with this game, please feel free to check out a play through that my friend and I did on our gaming channel to see if it is the game for you. Stop on by, and watch us laugh at things that are absolutely going to win us a front row seat in hell.

142769339.review:
This one left me a bit conflicted. The game has a very dark sense of humour as you explore a day in the life of a young girl from a broken home who decides to go on an adventure. Along the way you are given a look into her cute and wholesome misunderstanding of the gruesome world she lives in.

It has a very Eastern European sense of humour given how dark and bleak the goings on are but it's endearing to see the character take it all in stride and try to find the optimism in her naivety. The result is a comical point and click adventure that leaves you a bit torn between feeling concerned for her and curious at what exactly is going on since some of the events blur the lines between fantasy and reality.

There isn't actually much gameplay involved as you're just interacting with things and listening to dialogue for most of the game with occasional A or B choices that just leave room for 1 extra run through if you want to see the alternative events - though nothing that significantly changes the story - though there is a special ending if you achieve a certain goal.

Points for originality, but I get the feeling they could have just made an animated feature and gotten the same result.

142186034.review:
Beautiful game, but not everything’s great

The story is touching, the artwork is gorgeous, and it’s so cool to get into the Fran Bow universe once again. Thank you for the game! I absolutely recommend it to whoever is reading it.

However, there are things I didn’t enjoy. I’ll mark them as a spoiler to not ruin the gain experience.

[spoiler]
The game is boring to replay, though the game implies many times that you would want to replay it. Here’s what I mean:

1. Not meeting the expectations:
One you go through the game for the first time, Mr. Voice implies several times that you could do a different choice. This gives an expectation that the game won’t end on the first play-through. However, when you replay the game, you almost don’t get anything new.

The best example is when you feed the fish to the bird. In the first run the voice said 2 times that I could feed the fish to the drunk bird. You expect that if you do it next time you will get a new part of the story, but all that happens is that the bird eats the fish.

Or even a better one. That question from the voice — “have you heard this question again?” The voice didn’t react at all when he heard “yes.” You’d expect some fourth wall breaking here or at least some confusion from the voice.

How cool would it be if your actions were more important for the game plot. Maybe with more endings, or just adding fun details to the ending. Like, you enter the hamster club, and then in the end they help you escape the house or something.

2. Dialogs are too long. On the second play-through you already know every line of the dialogue. And skipping them is long. And then you skip-skip-skip and unintentionally start the dialogue again.

3. The true ending is not satisfying. It’s beautiful, and it would be fine if the second play-through was fun. But you repeat the same actions trying to find stuff you forgot to sprinkle, and get extra 20 seconds of the video. Like, I’ve spent an hour to go through the game again and that’s it?

[/spoiler]

In the end, just want to repeat that the game is really great. I super enjoyed the first play-through. I hope next time the replay could be more engaging!

142025759.review:
TLDR - 7.5/10       Buy on sale

Good:
 -Nice art style
-Good balance of funny and dark
-Engaging story

Bad:
-Short the first time through and even shorter on a replay
-Only really 2 endings

Ugly:
-Surprising lack of differences in replays
-Few choices have huge consequences to veer the story one way or another and most tend to be barely different ways to get the same result
-Gameplay is somewhat boring with the exception of a DDR clone in a hamster nightclub

Summary:
 Little Misfortune is a short story game following an 8-year-old girl travelling in a bleak world guided by a mysterious voice. The voice takes her around the town she lives as weird and spooky things happen throughout her adventure. It is up to the player to guide her on her journey to help her make the choices that lead to the best consequences for the little lady. Themes of depression, abuse, and death are abound but Misfortune keeps a happy attitude about it all, lightening the oppressive nature of the topics within.

All in all not a bad game but not one I can justify the full $20 asking price for. The game is mixture of too short, too mechanically simple, and lacks enough replay-ability for full price in my opinion. It took me seven hours to get all the achievements because I missed something my first playthrough, perfected my second, and tried for a negative ending on a third only to find there wasn't one. I got this game for about $7 in a sale and I'm fine with that number. Misfortune herself is a very interesting character and the story is good (not great) due to a lack of time and ability to really go in depth with anything. I may sound harsh towards this game but only because of the great potential it has that could have been expanded upon. Overall I suggest picking this up if you find it on sale.

141943493.review:
Having not played Fran Bow, like the other negative reviewers, I can't compare to it. But I hope the writing is more interesting than Little Misfortune's. 
The game is cute, has some fun humour here and there, and has a nice way of portraying a kid grown up too fast. But that's all there is. It has atmosphere and character, but no depth. Oh it touches upon a lot of themes, and it has plenty of symbolism and metaphors, but it doesn't do anything with them. I won't remember Little Misfortune after I have left this review, because it says nothing, nor does It shows anything new or interesting. Due to this It goes out on a limper, with a pretty meaningless additional "good" ending. 
And what few things it does say, if you were to really read into it, are pretty awful like:
[spoiler]That neglecting and letting your husband abuse your child is fine, as long as you still love your child
And that true happiness only exists as an illusion. You collect happiness points by removing the bad reality with glitter, and replacing it with happy childish fantasies. This is despite the game seemingly being critical about covering up real emotions
[/spoiler]

I would honestly never pay for this. Not because it's terrible or even bad, but because it will leave you with nothing after you turn if off. And this medium deserves better than that from its story based games.

141478855.review: Si vienes buscando algo parecido a Fran Bow, aquí no es. Little Misfortune es un juego lento, igual se demora más de una hora en que comience la historia y cuando crees que va a comenzar ya se ha terminado, literalmente saltan los créditos. Te vende humo con que tus acciones tendrán repercusiones, nada de lo que hagas tendrá nada de repercusión. Es un juego vacío, es lineal y no pide nada de ti, al igual que no te da nada. No aprovecha nada de la historia o del universo de Fran Bow, a lo mucho unos pequeños fanservices. Me gustaría poder decir algo positivo y sé que las comparaciones son tediosas, pero viniendo de la misma gente y situando el juego en el mismo universo, es imposible no hacerlo, hasta se siente más pobre en el apartado artístico. Casi todo lo hace mal, no sabe de ritmo, no sabe mantener tensión, la mayoría de chistes no funcionan o es el mismo pero en distintos contextos. Es incluso doloroso, una decepción sin más, por eso, no puedo recomendarlo ni siquiera en oferta.

141343374.review:
Ok.  Veces los videojuegos se enfocan tanto en la narrativa que es fácil olvidar que se trata de un videojuego, solo quieres seguir adelante para desmenusar los eventos y conocer tanto acerca del mundo que se te presenta como te sea posible. 
En este caso, considero que más que por una experiencia jugable, este título vale la pena sobre todo por su narrativa. Se eligió un estilo de juego bastante lineal, pero que sirve perfectamente para el propósito de la historia que se cuenta. Sí al igual que yo, eres capaz de apreciar un título con este enfoque, entonces encontrarás definitivamente una pieza de arte que se quedará contigo probablemente el resto de tu vida.
No es un título de larga duración, pero las actuaciones de voz, el cuidadosamente bello estilo artístico y la adorable personalidad de la protagonista te harán desear que este lo fuera, pues se construye un mundo que te da la sensación de tener mucho más que ofrecer a sus personajes. A pesar de que tiene cierta rejugabilidad debido a las múltiples decisiones que se te presentan, no se dejan cabos sueltos, aunque como dije, desearías que lo hiciera, para extender más la duración de este "juego" que Morgo propone.

141255683.review:
Little Misfortune is a fun game with an enjoyable game with a nice art style and a soothing soundtrack to go along with it. You can approach the game in many different ways and the game doesn't spoon feed you on what to do or what way you should play (which I do appreciate). The game does have a depressing undertone and with some things not being suitable for all ages but for me that's what gives this game its charm, it shows the depressing life that we all go through in the eyes of an 8 year old child who is oblivious to whats really going on around her which leads to some really funny moments.
There are some things that I don't mind that others may, for instance Misfortunes voice may become a bit annoying to constantly listen to.

[9/10] Would Recommend

141202370.review:
Little Misfortune is a thoroughly disappointing experience. I kept trying to find some redeeming qualities to try and justify leaving a positive review but i couldn't. Only thing Little Misfortune is good at is deceiving you into buying it by hiding its weaknesses with a coat of paint.
On the surface, it has beautiful visuals ,good voice acting and an interesting protagonist that is surrounded by tragedy. Under the hood though, it is just a boring walking sim that can't follow up on its own ideas. 
The game is advertised as an interactive fiction but the gameplay has a linear path that restricts you from going back where you came all together and won't allow you to move on before interacting with a key object, has pathetic puzzle/s that literally tell you what to do and is heavily centered on choices that change almost nothing.
The story is uninspired, unremarkable and relies solely on dark humor to make it interesting but fails miserably . It tries so hard to be mysterious and unpredictable yet everything is obvious from the get go and not interesting.
Unless you want to be disappointed, I recommend staying away from it. Not worth your money or time.

141040780.review:
This game wasn't for me. I found it a little too dark and distasteful. I usually appreciate dark humour, but this one is not very comedic and rather gratuitously tragic. For example *spoiler alert* early in the game Misfortune steps on doggy doo and throws up because of it, then a dog licks the puddle of sick *end of spoiler*. None of this moves the narrative forward or helps flesh out the character, it's just... potty humour I guess? But not a particularly sharp or clever one, just one that revels in bodily excretions.

The narrative is a bit inconsistent too, your choices in the game don't seem to matter too much. For example, *spoiler alert* there's a turning point early in the game where you have to choose wether you're going to tell George about losing his dog, but George was dead all along so it didn't really matter whether you decided to tell him or not *end of spoiler*.

If you're looking for a cutesy game that still appeals to grown up sensibilities I'd say this is not it. Any cuteness is undercut but deep, dark gratuitous tragedy. The artwork makes it seems like it's going to be just a bit mysterious, but in reality is much more gruesome.

Some things I loved about this game are the character design and the artwork. They are really beautiful. Another great thing about the game is that it has voices! It feels very cinematic because of it and I wish more indie point-and-click games invested in voice actors.

139906102.review:
I bought the game after considering the reviews on steam and didn't expect to dislike it.

To explain the review specifically, it'd require me to go into the specifics of content that would spoiling too much, so I'll just focus on what I can say.
For a game of its kind, it lacks the depth, engagement - the game makes a disproportionally huge deal of decisionmaking and the consequences in its narrative, which is an absolute joke when looking at the "consequences", which is barely even a working illusion (there is no decision tree worth mentioning - game doesn't even end differently). Despite being a short game, it also feels like it plays too slowly. The shortness could be justified, if it had any real replayability value filled with new experiences..
The story is nothing worth mentioning, besides being really simple and I suppose they didn't focus on making one either, rather focusing on the dialogue, which is incredibly samey samey. There are some moments of juvenile innocence when she talks about things adults may be more knowledgeable about that stick but that's it. Perhaps it's because I've played multiple narrator games in the past and expect more now. It is definitely a game that appeals to people less familiar with "what's out there" more.
I can't get rid of the feeling it's a case of "making the game longer than 2h so it can't be refunded", which frankly is an unfortunate aspect that has to be considered at times. 20 bucks is too much, especially knowing other narrator games, bigger, cheaper - and since this game tries itself at humour - funnier, that don't limit the speed at which you play. Do not that there are no challenges, puzzles and/or alike, everything is spoonfed, interaction icons popping up (you can only go left and right and not miss anything). Not saying that it had to have things like these, but if it's lacking demanding aspects, it should make up for it. I bought this game because I saw some dialogue/events in YouTube shorts - to think the ones I saw were the only "good" ones was pretty disappointing, also considering the other moments were basically the same, but a bit worse.

It sounds like I'm pretty harsh on the game, but I felt like elaborating on these aspects, since I'm already here writing a negative review. The fact that the game plays too slow (and yes, I know how to run, it's not just walking speed) is a bummer.

139315656.review:
The game is way too short - just 3 hours (I played it twice to get all achievements), way too simple, the game ends abruptly, just as things start to get interesting, and there is no satisfying closure. By being simple I mean that all you do is walk right and choose between A and B, there are barely any puzzles (just one?), no back-tracking, the game is very linear and very often the choices don't even matter. It's a walking simulator where you move from the start of the game to the end without any challenge.

While I'm fine with dark humor and fecal-funny jokes most of the time, and the humor in the game is fine, I feel like the game has overdone it just a little, especially when [spoiler]Misfortune was farting green clouds when stuck in a wall.[/spoiler] Also wtf was that sexually suggestive scene [spoiler]on the unicorn ride?[/spoiler], isn't she a little girl? That felt rather unnecessary.

The visuals are pretty, the voice acting is good, and there is some fun to be had, but don't expect too much from it and don't pay the whole $20 sticker price, get it on a sale or in a bundle.

Overall I can't recommend the game due to the shortcomings.

138943293.review:
A spiritual sequel to Fran Bow, but don't let that fool you, the story is not connected, characters are not (really) reoccurring, for the most part it doesn't even take place in the same universe. The only thing it really carries over for the majority of the game is the vibes the original had. Less visibly gruesome but jam packed with the good kind of dark humor and nihilism. I see why someone coming from Fran Bow might be disappointed, for the most part the games should be treated as separate entities, with this game only containing subtle hints to its predecessor.
It's a cute game with mostly shock humor, about a pure protagonist in an impure world. Childlike wonder and innocence in the face of a cruel and rotten reality. In that way, it's pretty good standalone title that's not much more than a really messed up picture book-esque walking simulator. It's almost unfair to compare to the studio's other game, as it doesn't try to fill the same niche. It's not really a puzzle as much as the original was, not a huge story with fantasy elements. Just a simple tale of an unfortunate yet optimistic little girl who can be corrupted by her environment.

138467849.review: Es un juego con arte visualmente muy agradable, un estilo tierno que contrasta con lo amarga que puede llegar a ser su trama. Su banda sonora logra transmitirte el sentimiento que el creador pensó para la escena, y no es juego particularmente complicado, lo que te ayuda a disfrutar de la historia sin romperte la cabeza haciendo un doctorado en Puzzlelogía para pasartelo. Personalmente, el que alguien creará este juego y logrará expresar tantas emociones, sentimientos y pensamientos con los que convivo día a día, me da una sensación de tranquilidad y nostalgia, saber que hay otras personas que tienen estas ideas y son capaces de transmitirlas para crear algo tan único, te llena de esperanza. Lo único malo es que ha sido demasiado corto para mi, y eso viene de alguien que se lo pasó 2 veces para sacar el final secreto. No importa cuantas veces lo pases, el juego siempre te transmite la misma energía que cuando lo juegas por primera vez. En resumen, es una obra desgarradoramente hermosa, que de alguna u otra forma te dice que no estas solo.

I was gifted Little Misfortune a while back from my father for Christmas, who had mentioned it "seemed like something I would enjoy."

I've already been a part of the Fran Bow and Little Misfortune fandom for a while, I suppose you could say.

Little Misfortune is still an unorthodox yet stunning, and awesome game with shocking as well as eye opening scenes, and a fascinating continuation of an interesting and extraordinary franchise.

With a quirky and distinctive art style, magnificent voice acting and stellar writing, this game often brings me to tears, and continues to boggle my mind.

To-this-day I still ponder over the narrative and story, and find myself enraptured by the universe Natalia and the Killmonday crew have created and continue to develop.

136498774.review:
"I'm a little lady, you know?"

After playing Fran Bow, I was immediately seeking out any other works by the same artists. I've been keeping this one in my back pocket to play on a rainy afternoon, and it did not disappoint.  

I want to clarify that there is VERY little actual game play in Little Misfortune. It took me about 5 hours to 100% it. It is mostly a point and click walking story, and most of the "choices" don't really alter things significantly, but if you like cute/morbid stories, it definitely checks those boxes. It's not nearly as dark as Fran Bow (which I also highly recommend you play if you haven't already), but this story definitely touches on some dark themes, and I thoroughly enjoyed the ending. 

I can't wait to see what else this game studio produces in the future, because they've already managed to create two games and tell stories that will really stick with me.

136157184.review:
PUNTUACIÓN TOTAL: *****/***** OBRITA DE ARTE ^^3  <3

-PRECIO: (Esto también según la economía de cada persona) Ahora está en Steam a 16'79€, pero yo lo compré por 2'40€. Su precio aquí me parece de ***/***** y el que conseguí yo fue de *****/*****.

-HISTORIA: *****/***** (Sin spoilers)
Wow, a mí me ha encantado, muy emocional, bonita, con puntos ligeramente previsibles y otros muy imprevisibles (recomiendo para cualquier juego que si quieres disfrutar de la historia, sorprenderte y demás, que no te pongas a buscar "qué está pasando", "quién es X o Y", "uy, lo que ha pasado es X"), en este caso yo no me esperaba en absoluto la historia "final" y me ha parecido todo increíble.

-JUGABILIDAD: *****/*****
Muy sencillo, WASD, ratón, según te mueves aparecen simbolitos que parpadean un poco para que sepas que puedes interactuar (hay diferentes formas para usar/observar objetos).

-ORIGINALIDAD: *****/*****
Es un point and click sencillo, entretenido, eso sumado a la historia, gráficos, etc, lo hacen original y maravilloso.

-DIVERSIÓN: *****/*****
He visto gente que lanza mucho hate porque les ha resultado "corto", a mí también se me ha hecho corto (2-3h), pero me ha resultado muy entretenido, curioso, bonito y la verdad es que aunque dure 2-3h como si lo hubieran creado de 10h, el resultado habría sido igual de excelente. Empápate bien y disfruta de cada diálogo, de cada decisión, de cada escenario y demás, porque así lo vas a disfrutar por completo.

-MÚSICA: *****/*****
Totalmente acorde a cada escenario, muy bien mimetizada, cuando la música ha sido correctamente seleccionada, ocurre que te adentras en la historia "casi sin darte cuenta de que está ahí" y te acompaña como merece en cada momento.

-AMBIENTE: *****/*****
Cada momento, cada escenario, etc, son totalmente idóneos y no te saca de la historia para nada, en cada momento y lugar "estás ahí viviéndolo".

-GRÁFICOS: *****/*****
Preciosos, parecen unos bonitos dibujos de cuentos (además que los tonos Otoñales han quedado perfectos, puesto que la historia ocurre en Octubre), no me resultan molestos en ningún momento, no he visto ningún fallo/bug.

En definitiva, recomiendo 100% este juego, y por favor, vive la historia intentando adentrarte sin "buscar los 3 pies al gato", disfruta, observa... <3

135952305.review:
//MINOR SPOILERS

First off, gonna mention that I'm Finswedish (not actually from Sweden but I speak the language) so it was really nice to understand the swedish references in this game! 

Now for the good and bad:

The good:
- Story was great and the concept is unique, you didn't really know what was gonna happen next and 
- The story was also perfect length. Nothing was per say rushed or dragged out too long. You felt like you got just enough time on it!
- Likeable characters. Missfortune is a cute, sassy child with a pure view of the world. She has some great one liners which made me chuckle and some more iconic ones like "Yikes forever!". Even Morgo is likeable just by his voice alone. 
- Unique artstyle and great music!
- A nice touch with some minor minigames like "Whack the fox" and "dance battle"! Made the gameplay more fun (especially since most of it is just walking and interacting).
- Achievements were also pretty easy to get, which is sometimes for games like these nice. 

The less good:
- Some game mechanics. I was playing with mouse and keyboard for example and I could only sprint when constanly clicking left click. Then I also was not able to sprint using my keyboard at all so it would've been better if I could do do that. Also maybe just holding the keybind so I wouldn't have to constanly click myself forward. 
- When doing my second run for achievements, it was a tad annoying to not be able to skip dialogue effectively or at some points not at all. I know this could be "countered" by just doing one run but using saves and loads but some people (like me) like to just do one run where you just enjoy the story and then a second one for achievements. 

Definetly recommend this game for people who like story based games! Happiness to you!

Really enjoyable game, but way too short to justify a $20 price tag...

I really enjoyed the game! Misfortune's dialogue and character is really funny and enjoyable. That being said, I do wish there was a little more story. There's a whole story that gets fleshed out near the end of the game from a certain character that we really don't get to see at all. It feels like we were going to meet a bunch of other characters that get shown throughout the game that we never really get any significant closure with, just alluded to their fate. And for a $20 price tag, it feels like there should have been more chapters in her story, or another characters perspective would have been really nice. All in all, I spent maybe 3-4 hours to beat, getting most of the achievements in my first playthrough and getting the final ending. 

TLDR; If your looking to play a short 4 hour game with a very likable character, wait for this game to go on sale for $5-$10 and enjoy!

135565479.review: if you're like me and don't consider yourself much of a gamer but *do* enjoy a good ol' point-and-click story game from time to time, this game could be great for you. with straightforward controls and instructions, a hooking storyline that's not too fast-paced but never slow and boring and a little creepy but definitely not too nightmare-inducing (at least for me lol) Little Misfortune took me ~3 hours to play once-through and was very entertaining with a very pleasing art style that I definitely appreciated. as someone that loves to read all the information that I can, I love that this game encourages you to look at/interact with everything there is the option to in order to collect all of the achievements, although I can't believe I only managed 16/35 on my first play through! at some point, I'll have to replay and attempt to finish off the list, but unfortunately I'm not especially hooked in to replay it immediately as I'm sure the storyline remains practically the same even if you make different choices. in conclusion, I paid ~£5 for this in the spring sale and don't regret it in the slightest, I really enjoyed this game, however I'm not sure I would have paid ~£15 due to its short playtime and lack of replayability. great game, though! and also, I'm just tight :P

135431742.review:
A witty, if irreverent, point-and-click game that is less puzzle and more narrative with a haunting premise.

"Little Misfortune", the game's titular protagonist, is tasked by the 'narrator', a mysterious voice inside her head, to complete a game to achieve "Eternal Happiness". The player is mostly along for the ride, but there's lots to interact with, find, and interpret, as there are more than a few aspects/themes that are never properly explained and thus open to interpretation, making for a unique setting despite familiar environments.

It's not super long, about 2-3hrs, but I recommend being as thorough as possible to get the full experience, there are lots of secrets to unlock and lore tidbits to find (not to mention a host of achievements to reward this style of play).

135138052.review:
An indie, choices-based game with strong themes wrapped in a childlike package. 

At first glance, "Little Misfortune" appears to be a simple and lighthearted game. You control the choices of a small character named Misfortune, who is blissfully unaware that she will be meeting her demise in the final chapter. Though the graphics are reminiscent of a children's picture book, the story-telling is anything but that. 

As you progress through the game, you begin to realise that there are much darker themes at play, cloaked by the whimsy of childlike innocence. The game shines a light on real-world tragedies, including murder, suicide, death, drug abuse, and childhood trauma.

Despite these heavy themes, "Little Misfortune" manages to maintain a whimsical and childlike atmosphere throughout. The other characters, along with Misfortune, are endearing and charming, with quirky personalities and humorous dialogue. 

So, if you're looking for a game that offers a unique and thought-provoking experience, while still maintaining a childlike sense of wonder, "Little Misfortune" is definitely worth checking out.

I got into this game when I saw funny and slightly twisted scene son tiktok. It looked weird enough that I skipped the videos to avoid spoilers. Finally, when I picked up this game I did not know what I was getting into. It has a "Courage the Cowardly Dog Vibe" silly at times, dark at times, with just enough weird to make it enjoyable.

135060484.review:
So I adore this game. It's so twisted but fun. A single run through only takes about 2-ish hours or so, so it's nice to just to zone out for a few. 

Pros:
- Simple game play
- Straight forward plot
- Pretty artwork
- Fun
- Benji is best boy.

Cons:
- Plot is too simple. 
- Choices really only impact achievements, not game itself.
- Play it once and that's kind of it

I hate saying it, I don't feel like there's a lot of replay value to the game, especially after getting all the achievements. Like I went through several runs selecting different options, and tried to get all the endings but there's really only one ending. Which is fine but like, it makes replaying the game boring and a little tedious.

Overall, I enjoyed playing Little Misfortune and I'm happy I bought it. I do recommend the game but don't expect a lot from it.

135001593.review:
A la altura de su antecesor, mas o menos...

Frankbow es el anterior juego de este estudio (otra obra de arte) que se me hacia pesado en ocasiones y demasiado lento entre otras cosas.

En missfortune se arreglan muchas de las cosas dando mas opciones y posibilidades que dan juego a la rejugabilidad y aparte destacar las voces que son IMPRESIONANTES, sencillas pero con personalidad. Tiene muchas cosas buenas pero le falta un golpe mas fuerte como tenia franbow. 

Toca temas oscuros pero nunca profundiza, deja caer puzzles pero son demasiado faciles y no hay ninguna dificultad en ningun momento del juego, andas de lado a lado haciendo alguna tarea o minijuego y poco mas.

Respecto a la historia me parece muy buena pero escasa ya que el juego lo puedes tener acabado con todos los logros en 4 o 5 horas maximo (otra vez comparado con franbow que tiene mas horas y es bastante mas complejo a la hora de puzles pero con la desventaja de no tener doblaje ni ese punto de humor siendo una contraparte mas "seria").

Recomiendo el juego? Sí, 100%, AUN así no creo que sea necesario comprarlo a precio de salida y creo que es un juego que se disfruta mas sabiendo que has pagado 6€ aprox en vez de los 16 ya que como dije, lo acabaras MUY rapido.

Es un pequeño juego echo con cariño que definitivamente merece tu tiempo.

Muchas gracias :)

134688520.review:
I really, really enjoyed Little Misfortune. There's something perfect about the blend of humour, dark humour, fantasy, real-world dark subjects, art, and surreal voice acting (I believe Misfortune is played by an adult South-American-born Swedish woman voicing a little girl speaking in English, creating the single strangest and most compelling accent I've ever heard). It really does feel like something special.
Highly recommend if you like strong characterizations, point-and-click/walking sim style gameplay, and aren't bothered by sometimes VERY dark themes.

134687040.review:
[h1] A Challenging and Haunting Adventure with Dark Themes[/h1]

This is not your typical game with a happy ending. This game delves into themes of abuse, death, and darkness that may challenge some players. 

From the start, the game sets an eerie tone reminiscent of a "Scary Eastern European Cartoon." You embark on an adventure with Little Misfortune and Mr. Voice, who warns her that she will die today, and every decision you make will have consequences. 

As you progress, the mystery surrounding Mr. Voice and his companion, the fox Benjamin, slowly unravels, and what starts as a simple story becomes a rabbit hole that ensnares you.

[b]As fun as it was I recommend waiting for a sale, as the game is priced a bit high. But, if you're willing to handle the game's dark themes and tone, Little Misfortune offers a haunting and thought-provoking experience that is worth playing. [/b]

This game is not for the faint of heart. It covers themes of abuse, death, and just generally isn't for people seeking a happy ending. 

Little Misfortune has that 'eastern european cartoon that scarred you as a child' energy. You follow Little Misfortune on her adventure with Mr Voice. Mr Voice tells you immediately at the start of the game that Little Misfortune will die today, and that consequences matter. You journey through the game to uncover the mystery behind Mr Voice, and the fox, Benjamin.

I can't say much more without spoiling things but the game's story starts simple and becomes a rabbit hole you will fall down. I can only say that I will recommend this game and it's experience if you are mentally able to tangle with the dark themes and tone of the game.

I had fun going through this game.
[list]
    [*]Except an interactive movie rather than a point-and-click game. There is no riddle or mystery. The vast majority of objet interactions are for dialogues only, there’s not real inventory either.
    [*]The game description says choices matter. Well, they don’t. Like not at all. Whatever you do, there is only one ending with the possibility of a small variant.
    [*]There’s no inventory. The objects you can collect sometimes and the choices you do have very minimal consequence, it’s just for achievements.
    [*]The story is cute and touching.
    [*]The dialogues are fun and funny. 
[/list]

So I had fun, but I would have preferred to do something else. I don’t recommend it.

132704750.review:
In the world dominated by people hiding behind their masks, frankness and open minded way of thinking are very rare traits. 

Truth and bluntness to the core are something that is very great description of whom Little Misfortune is: Very young lady with a huge heart and endless hunger for adventures. She, as a main protagonist, seems to be a very cute child, however the way she speaks or interacts with everything exposes a lot of adult influence, which not always might be so polite and colourful as expected from a child. However this is a positive sort of a thing, which makes everything seem to be more real - where not everybody are perfect, where good and evil are mixed up together, while morality may be as well very symbolic, depending on who is the judge and what sort of a choices are being made.

This simple click point game, offers us not only a choices or a specific story-line - it's a fictional world filled up with many interactive points, additional mini games and very individual ways of changes to be made (connected to certain achievements, sic!) in dialogues or more visual things. It depends on us the players if during the game we want our character to remain as more innocent and positive one, or if we want to expose through it more adult-like perspective on certain events. The entire gameplay should be about 2h long, however if you are this type of a person that enjoys exploration or achievement mastering - then oh well, you might end up stuck withing this game for at least 8+ hours. 

In my case - as a clumsy girl gamer - I had spend about 30h in it, re-doing some bits of this game, unveiling everything I possibly could and unlocking the main in my opinion achievement (eternal happiness) at the very, very end. I am absolutely delighted, entertained enough and even interested in more similar works made by the publishers of this title.

If you decide to spend any penny on Little Misfortune - feel fortunate to enter the realm, where not everything seems to be as it is. Definitely, you will not waste any money here and only gain a positive experiences.

132333917.review:
The Game stars Misfortune Ramirez Hernandez, an imaginative 8-year-old, who seeks the prize of Eternal Happiness, as a gift to her Mommy. Led by her new friend, Mr. Voice, they venture into the woods, where mysteries are unraveled and a little bit of bad luck unfolds. Little Misfortune is an interactive story, focused on exploration and characters, both sweet and dark, where your choices have consequences.

This game is a delight, but also very sad. If you like a story that takes you on an emotional rollercoaster, you will enjoy this one. It's filled with dark humour and topics, but also has some little silly things, such as the glitter throwing and Misfortune's fart jokes. It has an unique artstyle and it's very pretty to look at.

Despite the fact that I had already watched a full playthrough of this game several times, it gripped me from my heartstrings and got me to shed a few tears. It's a wonderful game worth playing for yourself, and I definitely recommend it.

132224745.review: Not as eerie and gory as Fran Bow, but both wicked and charming in its own way. There are some tie-ins and nods to the Fran Bow universe, which I'd gladly hear (or see... or play) more of. That said, there is hardly any challenge (or gameplay, for that matter) in Little Misfortune: You'll only pass through a series of multiple choice questions and three or so simple mini games. Still, Misfortune is a nice little filler for those late night hours when you aren't up for anything more involved. My girlfriend and I clicked through the full course and had - well, maybe fun may not be the best word here - but we had something of that sort.

132217104.review:
Huh?

No seriously, what? Is this game... a joke? It certainly [i] has [/i] a lot of jokes, many of which are thoroughly unfunny, I know that much... but what I want to know is, how and why did KillMonday go from an awesomely creepy point and click adventure game full of incredible imagination and intrigue (Fran Bow) to... a walking simulator about a girly fart machine? Pardon my bluntness, but seriously, aside from the climax, that's basically all I see this game as. Okay, there aren't that many fart jokes, but most of the jokes are still on the [i] level [/i] of a fart joke. I mean, for crying out loud, there's a POOP joke! ...Also a pee joke now that I think about it, but that one was less graphic. I guess if that kind of humor is your jam, then this game is probably right up your alley. But for me, I found myself cringing most of the time. And the gameplay really didn't save it... I don't have anything against walking simulators, but the point of them is for you to take in the scenery and the story, right? It's a game that doesn't rely on gameplay, basically. Well, that should sum up why the gameplay doesn't save Little Misfortune, then. Because it IS basically a walking simulator--I don't care if it's tagged with Point & Click on the store page--interactivity beyond walking is [i] very [/i] minimal.

Now, I will admit that the climax is quite cool, and started to make me finally feel genuinely invested. Thing is, the moment stuff finally starts getting interesting is the moment the game ends. Talk about a tease. Torture me with toilet humor for three hours, then give me thirty minutes of the imagination and intrigue I loved from Fran Bow, and then just... end?? Ugh. Could you be [i] any [/i] more frustrating!??

...It's not an awful game... there's clearly effort put into it, and quality in certain regards... again, if you like grossout (and macabre) humor, you'll probably enjoy this game. I don't mind macabre humor by the way--I haven't mentioned that yet I guess... there's a decent amount of that in here too. I just didn't mention it because I don't feel much towards it one way or the other. So yeah I guess my final thing to say is this: Little Misfortune is a Walking Simulator full of grossout and macabre humor, that ends off with an abruptly dramatic and imaginative finale. Sound good to you? Go for it. But I hated it.

131445625.review: As a huge fan of Fran Bow, I was so hyped to see the devs created another game. Truth be told, Little Misfortune is nowhere near as intricate, challenging, or complex as Fran Bow is, in the slightest. The graphics were cute and unsettling at times, the plot was worth following to reveal the truth, and the journey was generally enjoyable. However, the pace was extremely slow, the environments provided minimal interactions, and it felt pretty one dimensional. The choice-oriented approach kept things interesting, but even that aspect of the game could have been improved upon. [spoiler] Especially considering the only true way to influence the ending is to sprinkle your glitter in every possible place, rather than make fate-altering choices. [/spoiler] To me, it felt like a children's game with periodic crude adult humor/imagery. I'm hoping this was a time filler to keep fans satisfied while waiting for a Fran Bow sequel, otherwise the devs truly set their fans up for disappointment having us transition from the masterpiece Fran Bow to the "just good" Little Misfortune. [spoiler] One thing I did truly appreciate were the appearances of Fran Bow characters and the reveal that they are in the same universe. This gives me hope that Fran Bow may make a return. I swear I saw her driving past Misfortune when she was waiting to get into the zoo! [/spoiler]

130800082.review:
I was not expecting the game to be so grim, but I liked it a lot anyway. 

The cuteness of the artwork made the dark, creepy, and sad moments have more impact, though Misfortune's innocence and sweetness kept me entertained, and motivated to seek the Eternal Happiness for her, even as it became increasingly apparent that things were not as they seemed. 

Both voice actors did a great job of conveying the characters, and their interactions were entertaining. I also loved the art direction. The little touches of visual world-building, like the masks and the hamster nightclub, made the world feel unique (and the absurdity of the latter was particularly amusing).

There are a lot of choices in the game, that matter to varying degrees, though ultimately the story is mostly linear, so it's a bit more like a visual novel than a full 'choices matter' game. For me this is fine, but if you are looking for something very branching, this one might not suit you. 

Also take care if themes/images/mentions of suicide, death (particularly child/animal), domestic abuse, or mental illness are distressing for you, as the game deals with all of these.

130553020.review:
I wish I could choose a sideways thumb. Because my feelings on this game are so mixed. (For reference, I've never played Fran Bow, so I was a newcomer to the characters and universe.)

Some spoilers ahead.

THE GOOD

-Design-

Everyone's already commented on the great design. In particular, Little Misfortune's character design reminds me vaguely of Madeline from the PBS channel mixed with Isabella from Phineas and Ferb, but dark, whimsical version.

The atmosphere is very cool. The versions of each setting are neat. It's got a wonderful confusing effect that also serves the plot.

-Voice Acting-

I adore the voice acting all around. For both main characters.

It's SO tough to choose a little girl voice that isn't horribly grating, and I feel like the voice actor nailed that space between too exaggerated and too boring. I even found myself enjoying the silly catchphrases because the voice is so darn cute. The sayings felt really true to Little Misfortune's character and situation. 

The ratio of original dialogue to catchphrases is a bit off, as others have said, but overall I didn't mind the catchphrases and felt they added character.

-Themes-

I love the themes the game tackles. It felt like a really sympathetic, realistic portrayal of child ab*se and neglect and how an optimistic, thoughtful kid would react to that environment.

I greatly enjoyed throwing glitter all over everything and keeping the magic alive for Little (I'm sorry, LADY) Misfortune as she made her brave journey. 

-SPECIFIC SCENES-

I may have cried at the turning point in the plot. But that's partially because after hours of meh gameplay, the sudden emotionality really threw me for a loop.

Also a big fan of the knock, knock, knock sequence, though the suspense was short lived. It felt immersive.

The ghost children and the train platform were spooky and unnerving in a good way. The mask people made me nervous. The unresolved what-the-heck-happened-to-her-ghost-friend left me wanting more.

I would've loved to see that higher stakes and narrative tension sprinkled throughout the game.

THE BAD

-The Ick Factor-

Multiple reviewers have already commented on the uncomfortable s*xualization of an 8-year-old character. I wholeheartedly agree. 

It wasn't a problem for me when it was about the bleak world-building. That makes sense. 

It became a problem when it was directed at Little Misfortune herself. She may be a fancy little lady at heart, but she's still not a REAL lady. Also, she's been through enough, dang it. Leave the poor girl alone.

The climbing-through-the-window farting scene and the carousel scene were especially egregious and made me want to quit the game. It was nasty and added nothing of value. 

-Some of the Adult Jokes-

Occasionally the adult stuff was plain stupid, like the hamster strip club. Why? What does that really add? It was trying too hard for me.

People have also called out the period scene and the crush on the fox. I'm more neutral on those, since they feel relevant to the story and themes.

The whole point is her mother got trapped into an abusive life she hated because she got pregnant as a teenager, right? And that's realistically a fate that could await a teenage Little Misfortune too? But still, the period dialogue was sloppy and jarring, which made it pointless because it didn't land.

She's also 8 and very emotionally young, nowhere close to 17 or whatever age her mom was. So it's a stretch if that's what that was supposed to be.

Everything was so hit and miss. Mommy "hugging" strangers in the alley -- super sad, and also necessary to paint a grim picture of her world. Random swearing? Eh. Sometimes it worked for me, sometimes it didn't. 

I feel like overall, the dialogue could've benefited from some editing.

-The Ending-

The ending -- if you can call it that -- made the game almost pointless for me. There was next to no payoff. And it also makes the pricetag not worth it for me.

No resolution with the main antagonist. No resolution with the mom, if you don't get the right ending. No resolution with the fox. (I am glad tree branch doggy was there, though.)

I didn't even understand what happened, to the point I wondered if I was supposed to walk backwards through the fog or make a critical choice before the fog.

I missed 2 glitter opportunities, so I didn't unlock the real ending. And without the real ending, the story randomly stops. I had to YouTube it to figure out if I messed up or if I was missing alternative endings.

The real ending is somewhat more satisfying, but it could've used more screentime. It felt very rushed. The mother crying scene is by far the best part, and then it fizzles into nothing.

OVERALL THOUGHTS

I don't know. If you really love narrative games with nice design, and you play this genre regularly, there are some great moments in here. Especially if you love strong characters with a great personality like Little Misfortune. She is truly the fanciest of little ladies and also way cooler and tougher than me.

If the themes speak to you, or you like morbid humor -- the pinata joke made me sad laugh -- then it's worth a play.

I would only recommend grabbing it on sale, though, especially since there's no replay value.

130151325.review:
Little Misfortune is a wonderfully curated tale of a young girl who leads the player through a dangerous world with childlike wonder. The story is great with fun mini games, achievements to earn, and an appropriately written, hard headed main character.

The only issue I had was while playing with a controller, I wasn't able to run in the tutorial part. I was able to if I used my key board. After that, there was no issue until I reached that part again later and tried to use my controller again. Other than that, play was easy.

I would not get this for a child, however. There are [spoiler] alcohol/drug references, sexual humor, and abuse [/spoiler] mentioned in the game which Misfortune happily glosses over in game. However it might be a bit much if there are younger kids who want to hang out with the adults as they are gaming. The farts were funny though.

As far as "improvements" I do wish there were options for your journey to end early, like a quick time dodge event while rocks are falling and such. Because of other games that I've played it seemed like a natural thing that would happen in those kinds of areas so I was slightly disappointed when that wasn't the case. Also, I would love if the squirrels would react when you hit them.

All in all, the game was worth the time. My copy was gifted but I would have been pleased with it if I bought it as well.

Little Misfortune es una aventura interactiva que nos cuenta la historia de la pequeña Misfortune Ramírez Hernández, una niña de 8 años que tiene una vida bastante dura y que se ve envuelta en un viaje hacia lo desconocido con mucha fantasía y misterio.

Pros:
- La historia y la ambientación están muy bien conseguidas.
- El universo de fondo en el que se desarrolla, con múltiples referencias a Fran Bow.

Contras:
- Cero jugabilidad, salvo algún pequeño minijuego.
- Lento en general, tanto al desplazarse como al intentar saltar los diálogos rápidamente.

Conclusión: Little Misfortune es una buena aventura para experimentar una tarde. Su duración, de unas 3 horas, y su carencia de dificultad lo convierten en una experiencia tranquila para quienes no quieran ninguna complicación y solo pretendan disfrutar de una buena historia. Si se ha jugado antes a Fran Bow se puede comprender mucho mejor el universo en el que sucede y muchos detalles que se cuentan en la historia.

Puntuación: 6/10

Wish I could give neutral recommendations instead of just "yes" or "no". I liked this game, you immediately feel sorry for Misfortune, and the story is compelling enough to get you through the game, BUT I think it fell a little short in some parts, and it's not for everybody.

I'm particularly disappointed by the ending, not because it was a bad one, but because it's only ONE. I played the game 3 times to get all the achievements and cinematics (you can get them all in 1 run if you follow a guide, also the game is short -like 2 hours- so it's not tedious), each time choosing different actions and responses but found out that doing things differently only shows you a slight variation in the events or dialogues that don't really matter in the end, so it's just an illusion of choice which is something I personally don't like (and I guess that's part of the theme of the game), but it's still entertaining to see what happens with each choice in the moment.

Other than that, I really like the art and voice acting. Misfortune's voice at first was a bit annoying imo but I got used to it and now I find it 'fancyyyyy'.

Note: This game is NOT for kids. I've seen some parents asking if they could purchase this for their children/or play with them. Please don't, it has a lot of mature topics (some of them are just there for shock value and don't add much to the plot).

129515271.review:
I vaguely remembered watching a play through of this game when it came out & that's what got me to buy it in the first place. This game is dark which is exactly what i wanted. The narrative isn't completely mind blowing, but its nice & well crafted, it drives home the points & characters it creates.

My first play through took roughly three hours, i was really taking my time, trying to do the most i could. I did a second run to get achievements, took me roughly two hours. It kind of killed me. This game is story based, like, entirely story based. The replay value isn't very strong because of that. I do love the story & it pulls my heart strings, but i'd be lying if i wasn't bored during my second playthrough (there was roughly two weeks between these completions). In my second playthrough i also tried how much of a difference my decisions actually made: aside from key moments, the game had a tendency to circle around back to the narrative that needed to continue (you could say no, but you eventually needed to say yes to continue). This is not a problem for me though, since from a writer's point of view its very understandable. 

Little Missfortune has little to no actual game play, its very much a point & click adventure where you make the most difference with your decisions. The atmosphere is nice, at some points i just felt like there weren't any stakes at play. When i was supposed to hurry & make a decision i was calmly clicking around because i knew i wasn't gonna get punished for it. In a way this game reminds me of a visual novel, something like Doki Doki Literature Club. 

The art is absolutely fantastic. I feel like the visuals carry a lot of this game & make up for the parts that were lacking. 

If you want a heartbreaking narrative of a little girl struggling to cope in her situation with beautiful artwork & a lot of dialogue, this game is for you.

129388840.review: I loved how spontaneous and random the story is. I get that this was a choice game and I would have liked to see a few different endings based off the choices you made. So, that threw me off a little bit but other than that, I loved the writing and the many witty moments this game had! 129387712.review: This game is about as average as it's possible to be. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing, mind you—Little Misfortune isn't especially bad at all. Rather, it's devoid of anything truly impressive, lovely visuals and charming voice acting aside. Some of the jokes are chuckle-worthy and the music is lovely. The story is piecemeal with gaping holes, often going for shock value or "edgy" humor rather than something sincere, and it suffers for it in the endgame when it tries to steer itself back onto serious ground. But my inner 12-year-old can't help but like the effort in spite of all of this, and I do hope the developers' next game harnesses the strengths but with a more solid story and better game-play/exploration elements.

126876738.review:
You'll enjoy this if you're looking for relaxing gameplay, an emotive story, beautiful art and quirky characters.  However, if you're looking for proper puzzles, multiple endings, a satisfying resolution or a brilliant twist, you may want to pass it by.

Little Misfortune was fun to play.  Gameplay is very simple, and although it's nominally a point-and-click, it's far more like a visual novel in the sense that you're just prompting the story forward rather than solving puzzles.  This didn't bother me, but would be a deal-breaker for some players.  There are choices which affect the story lightly in the moment but have no impact on the conclusion.  The character of Misfortune is brilliant; she has far more personality than most protagonists.  She attracts us to her with her many idiosyncrasies, rather than just reeling in our pity with her circumstances.

On completing the game, though, I didn't really feel satisfied.  One of the twists is already revealed to us at the beginning of the game, and the second is obvious from very early on.  "It was all magic" never washes with me as a resolution, and it makes the whole journey seem rather purposeless.  The game is very short, as if some later chapters that gave more explanation and a proper conclusion were just cut to save costs.  I also thought that the inclusion of the Fran Bow world was rather lazy; it didn't make much sense, and in fact, required the player to have previously played Fran Bow in order to make any sense at all!

It's a recommend from me, but not without caveats.  I'm glad I played it.  However, it really depends what sort of gameplay you're looking for.  I would also recommend buying on sale; the play time is much too short to justify the price, and there is little replay value.

I look forward to more from these developers, but my suggestion would be for them to move away from the Fran Bow world and make a completely standalone game - one which has a worthwhile twist and resolution.  If a story is sold to us as a mystery, we need these elements in order to be satisfied.

125217852.review:
This is a good game but, like everyone is already pointing out, I wouldn't recommend trying to playing it if you expect a game similar to Fran Bow. There are some parallels between the games' stories but the gameplay is very different and much more limited.

In truth, I believe that this game was made for a slightly younger demographic than Fran Bow was. There are plenty of "gross" jokes, most specifically fart, throw up, and poop jokes. These may be funny to some people, but they didn't properly contrast the story's seemingly lore-filled plot in my opinion. They came off as more annoying than anything.

So why do I still recommend this game when it's humor is very obviously not my cup of tea?

As limited as the gameplay was, I actually quite enjoyed it. It was fun to explore each choice we could make, to watch the cutscenes that came up throughout the story, and even just to explore what we actually can. I got this game on discount which I'd recommend doing if you REALLY do want to play it, as I don't feel it's worth the price otherwise.

you'll be done with it in under 3 hours and there is no real point in replaying, since your "choices" do not influence the story whatsoever. 
even though i appreciated the minigames as a way to break up the monotony, i'd rather the time and energy spent on that would have gone into expanding the core gameplay and story.
in the end it feels more like a click-through novel, which is fine if youre a fan of purely story-driven games, but i was missing the agency and involvement to really get invested and enjoy it.

I absolutely adore this game. From the excellent voice acting and dialogue, to the art style, to the music, to the story. I've played through three times and enjoyed it every time. It took me about 10 hours to complete all 35 achievements, so it's a quick play. You have to play at least twice to get all of the achievements. 

I adore the main character. She has the cutest voice and I love the funny things she says and throwing sparkles.

I would recommend playing Fran Bow and then Little Misfortune. They're both amazing games in the same interconnecting universe with similar themes, and there's quite a few references to the former in Little Misfortune. Fran Bow is creepier than this game, while this one has creepy elements with sweet/cute moments mixed in. The puzzles in Little Misfortune are few and not as complex as Fran Bow, but I enjoyed the cause/effect aspect with different choices affecting the story.

124683795.review:
[b]What is this?[/b]
A risky buy - a title like this could easily turn out to be irritating, virtue signaling, and all sorts of "bad stuff" without a refund window long enough - but I took the plunge. After all, Killmonday previous game, Fran Bow, was brilliant with a narrative similar to "Jacob Ladder's" / Rubber Reality type movies. 

NO regret on this one. This one is brilliantly voiced, the graphics are on point, and it's one of the rare games where I laughed out loud at the omnipresent dark humor. For those that worry about the recent trend in "woke" titles - do not fret:  while there is indeed a deeper social commentary, it never pull at your heartstrings or ramming a "message". 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
It's not a point-and-click adventure, more of a walking simulator with a very linear narrative introducing "choices" which give a sense of immersion (evidently no real consequences but it's believable enough). There's no puzzle, no platforming - purely a story that's paced extremely well. 

[b]Tech consideration and conclusion[/b]
I didn't encouter a single bug, and while it doesn't support 32:9, it's not important - the visuals hold their own. Musically, it's okay, sound effects are on point but the star of the show is the protagonist, voiced to perfection. 

If you like story-rich games- you'll love this. 
9/10 - another brilliant release from Killmonday games - a studio that's going from strength to strength.

124523384.review:
Little Misfortune is, without a doubt, a very peculiar indie videogame that stands out for its hand-drawn style, a particularly dark and somewhat satirical humor, and moments that will make you feel diverse emotions and mixed feelings. If you like humor, emotional moments, and decision making, I invite you to delve into this review! 

The game is presented to us as a classic point & click, where we must guide the little protagonist, Little Misfortune, on her journey in search of "eternal happiness". She, in turn, is guided not only by the player himself, who takes a role from beyond the fourth wall, but also by a mysterious narrator who advances the plot with a series of simple missions but that usually have in common a very predominant moral in the game: your actions have consequences. 

Throughout the game, we will be presented with moments where the aforementioned moral will apply, and we will have to choose between two options. At first they may seem unimportant or simply funny decisions, but as the mysterious narrator informs us, each choice will have its own consequence; either beneficial for our protagonist and those involved, or of course detrimental. 

As our protagonist's adventure progresses, we will encounter certain mysteries and uncertainties regarding the story and its characters, more specifically with the narrator, Misfortune and an enigmatic little fox that we will chase in search of solving a series of questions: Is he a friend or an enemy, what is he trying to communicate to us, and even more importantly, can we pet him?

The game's visuals are beautiful and detailed. Its hand-drawn art is charming, and one of the game's standout features is that it gives it a traditional, picture-book look. The soundtrack features varied musical tracks that help set the mood of each situation. From happy and lively melodies to tense and somewhat gloomy ones.

It should be noted that the title has voice lines for almost all dialogue (except for a couple of characters), and of really good quality; something you don't see every day in an indie game, and which is one hundred percent appreciated. In conclusion, its audiovisual section is very well worked and gives a glimpse of the effort of the developers in that aspect, which is key for this type of video game genre. 

The gameplay on the other hand is not hard at all. It's the classic gameplay of any point & click game. We can move from left to right and select objects, entities and other things to interact with them. As we perform these actions, Misfortune will share her thoughts with us, and usually the narrator will have something to say about it. Since it has such a simple gameplay style, which isn't a bad thing, anyone can play it and enjoy it without any problem; a big plus.

I don't want to spoil anything so I'll only say it's a quirky, entertaining and interesting game. The tonal shifts from humorous to emotional, from gloomy to happy and so on, can keep you playing for quite a while, either out of curiosity or just plain fun. It's a short story that makes us think twice with each choice, as the outcome is usually different and affects the following options that will be presented to us.

To close this review, I would like to share with you that personally, I am not a big fan of this genre (I don't hate it, but I don't love it either), but I really enjoy indie games; and, since several people recommended it to me, I decided to give it a try to see what it was like. Undoubtedly, it is a game that entertained me throughout its story. As I have already mentioned, its audiovisual section is very captivating, and its voice acting is the finishing touch. 

All in all, a game that anyone can pick up and enjoy, especially recommended for fans of point & click adventures, bittersweet stories and fluctuating humor!
