124293154.review:
Acabo de terminar Little Misfortune y esto es todo lo que puedo decir de este juego:

Little Misfortune nos presenta un juego de desplazamiento lateral con un montón de interacciones con todos los elementos que nos vamos encontrando. Algunos más próximos y otros más cercanos al final del juego que van cambiando partes de nuestra historia.

Este juego nos va a llevar por una serie de emociones y luchas contra nosotros mismos para poder completar todas las pruebas que nos vayamos encontrando. Todo esto nos lo presenta a traves de varios personajes que iran cogiendo personalidad y protagonismo a lo largo de la historia, hasta que descubras quien es quien en este entramado de personajes, emociones, interacciones y consecuencias

Arte:
Se presenta como un juego muy cuidado, dibujado a mano con mucha expresividad en los diseños y en los fondos. Llegando a generar una atmósfera completa, como ya pudimos ver en otros juegos de la misma compañía como Fran Bow

Banda sonora:
Realmente no se si he estado muy metido en la idea visual y en la historia pero no he percibido una verdadera banda sonora a lo largo del tiempo que tienes el control del personaje. Pero la banda sonora ha cobrado un protagonismo brutal en las cinemáticas del juego

Historia:
Intentaré contaros lo que me he podido sentir de la historia sin haceros spoilers. He podido ver un crecimiento muy notable del personaje protagonista. 

Empieza la historia teniendo conflictos con su familia y mostrando todo de una manera realmente cruda (incluso algunas veces con un tono de humor negro) que te hace sentir empatia con el personaje y sentir todo lo que ha sentido. 

Como ya he dicho hay acciones que conllevan repercusiones que iremos viendo a lo largo del juego.

Gameplay:
Nos presenta un juego básicamente de desplazamiento horizontal con eventos e interacciones. 
Al principio pensé que vendría mejor una interfaz de “Apuntar y clic” para ir indagando en todos los secretos del juego pero mientras vas avanzando, puedes ver que han elegido bien ya que no necesitamos más. Encaja perfectamente.

Valor por dinero:
Quizás sea lo único que flaquea el juego. Ahora mismo está aproximadamente a 17 € lo que hace que esté un poco caro para el tiempo de juego que le he dedicado (aproximadamente unas 5 horas). Aunque creo que aun me falta otra ruta de juego, por lo que puedo ver en los logros

Esperaros a una oferta porque el juego realmente vale la pena.

124033002.review:
I want to recommend this game (although interactive story is a better description) simply for the love and effort I can see has gone into making to it.  But if I was aware of certain content in it, I certainly wouldn’t have bought it.

The game itself has a very interesting and thought-provoking concept, which pulls you into a bizarre journey.  The artwork is beautiful and haunting, and the voice acting really fits the characters.  The game is a linear story, with point-and-click interaction, although there are some path-altering choices to make along the way, which give the game some replayability if you want to get all the achievements.

The problem I had with the game (trying not give spoilers) is all the sex and drug references, as well as all the swearing from the 8-year-old girl, Little Misfortune.  As I said earlier, if I had known about this to start with it would have put me off buying it.  The game would work just as well if they just left out the swearing.  She is a “little lady” after all.    If you don’t mind this/or even enjoy it, then the story is worth the time.  I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale though.

I have never had a game play with my emotions so much before. I laughed and I cried. I feel both fulfilled and empty at the same time. This game cured my depression and then threw it back in my face.

I picked this game up on a whim when it was on sale, and wow am I glad I did. Little Misfortune brings you along on a tale of an 8 year old girl in search of her Eternal Happiness. You are presented with choices that have consequences which will either seem considerable or insignificant to the story. There isn't much to do aside from controlling the character down the story-line while being presented with some humorous dialog as well as some serious topics along the way. I absolutely recommend picking this one up, but make sure you bring some tissues and glitter.

123392610.review:
The humour in this game is dark so if you're twisted like me, you'll find it amusing at the least. If you're not, you might struggle to get through it. There's a lot of TW topics in this game and it's unapologetic about it, including violence, substance abuse, and self-harm so do be conscientious of this when buying it if that's something that could upset you. The game itself is really good and I enjoyed the little adventure despite how sad it really was.

The game is short and far from sweet, and you're left wondering about this lil' lady and the tragedy that is her life.

I wasn't a huge fan of some of the mechanics of the game, specifically having to skip through conversations - using space bar was a nightmare as it sometimes restarted the conversation and you'd have to spam the key to move on and JFC the amount of times I kept doing this was infuriating. A simple fix would be for me to slow down, but I feel like a skip-button would have been good here. The graphics are different but still very pretty. The narrator was excellent and actually made the whole game feel like you were having a book read to you. Overall the voice-overs were very pleasing and added to the feel of the entire game.

Overall a good game and very entertaining. My favourite part was Benjamin describing the way he feels about Misfortune in his little diary. So weird, so amusing.

If you are an achievement hunter, I HIGHLY suggest you use a guide to avoid having to speed run the game a second time. Most games I wouldn't suggest to run the guide on your first play, but this game was quite annoying to get achievements for, specifically because you had to go through all of the dialogue etc. it was unexpectedly frustrating.

I'd also suggest that if you're buying this game, you wait for there to be a sale. The game takes a couple of hours to complete so it's quite short for what you pay.

I got this during Sale. It's cute and all, but it's definetely not as good as Fran Bow. It's quite short for the original Price, so I'd recommend getting it during sale, just like I did.
To be honest, I expected more from that game. Especially because of Fran Bow.

The graphics are good and the gameplay is fun and interesting. As some comments already mentioned tho, your choices don't really matter, even tho the games says they matter a lot. 
Only choice that i recommend you to do is to take the fish with you. If you don't you miss out on 2 achievements. You don't get any achievement if you don't take the fish with you, so it's better if you take it with you.
It has some dark jokes, but they are quite dry and only make you chuckle at best.
I wasn't able to feel sad or happy because of the characters. They felt too dry for me to sympathize with them, and the game ended too quickly as well for me to join in the feels.

I don't regret buying it, even tho I mostly said bad things about the game so far. As I said before, the game is still fun, but you can finish it in 2-3h, so it's good for fast achievements.

All in all, the game gets a 2/5 from me, and 1.5/5 if I would've gotten it for full price.

The story of this game is REALLY interesting. And while Misfortune's chatter can be a bit annoying at times, she's generally cute. Kudos on the Hamster club btw! lol

That said, I feel like --for all the choices you get-- NO Choice actually MATTER.

Seriously... I wanted to keep playing with Mr. Voice? Why can't I choose to go with him?! *Pouts*
I liked him.... >_>

It was a bit two-dimensional in it's game-play, but again, that wasn't the main reason I vote this game down.

I REALLY hate games who refuse to give you REAL choices!

If Gotham City was real, and I'd met the Joker, odds are I'd totally go with him over Batman. Terrified as Hell, yes, but I stand by my choice non the less.

My Point is: What's the point of choosing anything if what you choose doesn't matter? ><

I was really looking forward to play with the Monster at the very end too... *Sigh*

Why am I not allowed to make bad choices? I LIKE making bad choices!

Stupid choice-less game... *Glares*

Maybe I'll play it one more time and avoid clicking on a few key items... maybe that'll work. *Sigh* It's not exactly a choice you CAN make if you don't want to miss out on things in games, but maybe, just MAYBE there's an OPTIONAL ending if you don't.

Maybe... *Sigh*

I am VERY disappointed.

122601939.review: loved this game, it was hilarious and dark.

122598876.review:
Little Misfortune is one of those things where I'm shocked it is not more popular than it is. The story that unfolds is not a happy one, but Misfortune's spirit and the overall quirkiness of the story (plus the fantastic graphics!!) sets a good balance to all the bad parts. More of an interactive story than a game; as you follow Little Misfortune, your engagement with the story has the air of talking back to your favorite Sesame Street character when you were four years old. The story is brief (2-3 hours it takes to finish). Still, the length seems fair since I feel like the style of gameplay would have started dragging if the story had gone on for too long. In my opinion, what makes everything work is the voice acting. I would have liked the game without it, but with it, Little Misfortune carved "Happiness to everything!" into my heart. Fancy!

My wife purchased Little Misfortune for herself, and I decided to play Killmonday Game's previous release Fran Bow first. Outside of both being set in the same universe, having some dark elements, and quirky graphics, they are two completely different games. I appreciate that I took the time to play Fran Bow first. While previous understanding of the universe both stories are set in is not necessary to enjoy Little Misfortune, I think knowing more details helped me better understand the story established during the brief 2-ish hour game. It also made me squee during the handful of cameos.

[b]You might like Little Misfortune if:[/b] You like quirky dark modern fairytales.
[b]You might not like Little Misfortune if:[/b] Stylized gore and dark fairytales are not your thing.
[b]My favorite part:[/b] I now have new things to yell at speeders.
[b]My least favorite part: /b] There is not a part 2 already.
[b]Hours played as of review:[/b] 3
[b]Completed?[/b] Yes
[b]100%?[/b] Yes

122448475.review:
The artstyle and theming is really promising, but it could have been truly great if it was complimented by fun gameplay. Little Misfortune is a 2D walking simulator with very little of the kind of interaction that you would expect out of a videogame. There aren't really any puzzles and most branching paths seem to not change the overall plot at all. I didn't finish the game but I think I only missed an hour or so of it so it's pretty short.

All-in-all, I'd recommend that you buy it on sale and crucially IF you like the trailer. If you're curious about the plot and are fond of the thematic design then I'm confident that you'll get something out of it, but if you're looking for a tight story woven into a fun gameplay loop then it's a hard pass.

121591745.review:
[TL;DR : if you like short, cute, weird little stories ; and if you liked the cinematic : play this game. I promise, you'll like it.]


Honestly, an incredible little game. I can't wait to see more from them. I've also watched a whole playthrough of Fran Bow back in the days. I recommand them both, but Little Misfortune absolutely won my heart by its cuteness. 

This enjoyable experience brings you : 
- A short involving story, one that you will want to re-do just to see the little "consequences" of your different actions. 
- A deeper (but not too deep nor hidden, let's keep things simple and enjoyable) story narrated from a child POV
- A very neat art design with a main art style and an alternative one for the cutscenes and close-ups. It might not be for everyone but in my case, I loved it to bits. 
- A small bridge between Fran Bow and this game by placing a few references here and there (that won't stop you from understanding the game. Don't worry, those are just little eastereggs) that will definitely make Fran Bow's players smile
- And more importantly : amazing voice actors and characters.

I can't express enough how much I loved the character of Misfortune ; but firstly, let's talk about Mr.Voice. Mr.Voice's voice was just awesome. He was always on point and I actually loved to hear them both talk over everything. His personality was what you'd expect from him but it was efficient, and it got the job done. But Misfortune ? Misfortune was just perfect. The little laughs, the weirdness of an actual child, the tone, the personality, the way she'd say some words or the letter "j" sometimes. I don't know. It actually represented what a child is for me : a combination of raw honesty, innocence, selfishness and impulsivity. 

In terms of negative points, I don't think there are any. 
There are only two things I could discuss about : the character of Benji was a bit forgettable in my opinion eventhough it was an ok character but I think it might be because Mr.V and Misfortune were actually so well-written, that they kinda outshined the rest of the characters. This is probably on me. But still, I wanted more. And secondly, I was a tad disappointed by the last cinematic of the game and hoped for more than what was delivered. (Not the actual, actual last cinematic. More like the end of "the game" cinematic)
But apart from that. Fantastic game

121070497.review:
What you should know about this game is that it is NOT a puzzle game. It is an interactive fiction with small choices that might change a dialogue or minigame, but the story is otherwise entirely linear. Little Misfortune is similar to most interactive walking sims: trek around in a map, learn the lore through the character's commentary on certain items, play a couple of simplistic mini games, carry around items that are automatically used later down the line, all that stuff. The game mostly stands out for it's unique, hand-drawn, Burton-adjacent art style and the classic Killmonday themes of traumatised children who don't realise everything they have to say is horrifically morbid. 

Out of the two Killmonday games, I prefer Fran Bow for the overall darkness, scares, puzzles and visual creativity, however, Little Misfortune is clearly trying to take on a more charming and down to earth approach, and is successful in doing so! In this game you're supposed to feel a deep sympathy and love for Misfortune, a sweet 8 year old girl who sprinkles things with glitter and always has a smile despite the nuclear state of her family. The game didn't have any of the dark, gruesome metaphorical, surreal imagery that I was excepting after playing fran bow, but I still believe Little Misfortune was made with passion and hard work, which deserves my appreciation and respect for the creators.

TLDR: This game is purely interactive fiction (no puzzles) and is much less horror-driven than Franbow but still a good standalone work of art and fiction!

120587696.review:
I will try to give  a brief review with no spoilers first then include my review with spoilers below. Now, let’s first go over the pros and cons of this game:

Pros:
Music in this game was nice and relaxing
Misfortune is a cute character
The artstyle is great! 
The voice acting is on point. I love the character voices.

Cons:
The choices
The ending
The overall story
Gameplay

Now, I will speak on the story with spoilers below, but I will speak on gameplay first. If you ever played Fran Bow, which is in the same universe as Little Misfortune if I’m not mistaken, then you know that the game had puzzles to it. You would have to find items and use them on characters to progress through the story and you could swap between the different realities to meet certain characters or gain certain items. In Little Misfortune, there was really not a lot of interactive sections like in Fran Bow. You could look around and examine items around you and listen to Misfortune’s dialogue, but not many puzzles which can make gameplay feel repetitive and bland. I feel like this game would have been more fun had there been more puzzles and interesting choices to make which I’ll touch on now.

The choices in this game do not matter. My biggest problem with this game is the illusion of choice. The game wants you to believe that your choices matter and that they will have a big impact on the story. In the beginning of the game they literally tell you that a choice you make is very very important but it isn’t. It doesn’t change the story or affect your ending. There is only 1 thing that affects your ending but I’ll speak on that in the spoilers section. However, I hate games that say you should be careful of your decisions but don’t do anything with it. It just feels like a cheap aspect of the game to make it seem deeper than what it is.

Now I’ll discuss the story, but I will be sure to not spoil. The story is painfully predictable. I played with my sister and we easily guessed the story from the beginning. I will say that this game did a better job with understanding it’s story than Fran Bow, but at the end I didn’t feel satisfied. I felt like I spent 5 hours playing a game hoping to see what my choices led to only to be disappointed at the end with a predictable, cliche ending. Even looking over details of the story after the fact made me even more confused and ruined my experience. I really value a good story and a good experience and I feel like Misfortune missed the mark. 


Now I will speak on spoiler things such as the story from this point forward. DO NOT READ FURTHER IF YOU DON’T WANT SPOILERS!

The story:

[spoiler]Like I had guessed from the beginning of the game, Misfortune is dead the entire time. I was so disapointed because I feel like that is so cliche and overdone. Maybe if there was a twist on it I would have liked it more but nope. I hated this twist. Not only that, but I couldn’t understand for the life of me why ‘Mordo’ the monster would continue playing a game with a girl who was already dead? And Benjamin is supposed to be a protector, BUT COULDN’T EVEN PROTECT MISFORTUNE?! Also, there was no explanation of where Misfortune went at the end and I also had a problem with the ‘true ending of this game.’ There is no secret that Misfortune is being neglected by her parents. However, with the true ending, if you used your sparkles on every item you could (the only thing that matters mind you) then Misfortune’s mother would receive ‘Eternal Happiness’ I just find the whole thing of receiving happiness after her own daughter passed to be such a terrible message. The body wasn’t even moved off the road yet! I can sympathize with her mother being forced to marry an abusive man simply because she got pregnant, but she also greatly neglected her child and put her dangerous situations. I guess Misfortune’s mom’s only way to true happiness was to have her daughter get run over by her abusive husband. I guess she is free to live her life now. Sorry, rant over.[/spoiler]

I really really wanted to love this game. I had seen the trailers and I was so excited to play. I waited for reviews to come out and saw that a lot of people liked it! But I was so disappointed. This game is surface-level at best. It looks nice from the outside but it doesn’t have depth. I wouldn’t replay this game if I hadn’t gotten the true end the first time. I was bored looking at items and only listening to dialogue. I was so deeply disappointed by the ending and I feel like this game is a pass. 

I wouldn’t recommend this game unless you got it on a massive sale. If you don’t care for good stories and branching paths then give it a go, but if you’re like me and enjoy games like Heavy Rain or the Anthology Series where your choices actually matter and can lead to interesting story branches and endings, then skip this one. I mean no hate to the developers of this game but I feel like they could have used their great talents to make a truly developed game. 

 Misfortune didn’t give what it was supposed to have gave. 

4/10 Would not play again.

119565687.review:
I think this game had great potential but for me at least, it never really reached it. It's your standard "cute but dark" interactive storybook (there's a few mini-games and choices with consequences, but otherwise not much gameplay - which is fine).

I did enjoy it overall I'd say, with the best things about it being the overall story and some genuinely surprising moments. However, some things fell pretty flat for me. The darker elements of the story are very on-the-nose (especially the main character's dialogue about her parents) I think it would have strongly benefited from more subtlety. The humour fell extremely flat for me (such as when the game interrupts the story to have the main child character fart for 10 seconds - just why?), and I really struggled with the pacing - it's verrryyy slow. Especially for a game meant to be replayed, there should really be more options to skip dialogue or just move faster in general. The child's voice acting is also *fine* but personally I found it pretty grating after not too long.

All that said, I didn't dislike this game as a whole, and I played it through twice. For $30 though, I don't know that I would recommend it, and I'm not sure why it has such a high price tag for pretty simple animation and gameplay, especially compared to other similar games. I don't *not* recommend it, but I don't particularly recommend it either - probably worth picking up on sale if it sounds like your kind of game.

119484193.review:
This game was something I had a lot of fun with although it deals with a lot of sad topics. Alcoholism, Drug abuse, Child Abuse, Domestic Violence, Missing Children, Depression, Suicide, Death, A child predator with a town a little too apathetic to that fact, among other things, so it isn't really for someone who may find these topics triggering.

That being said I do think this game is a little indie gem and worth the playthrough. Especially since in no way does it try to glorify any of the sensitive topics above but rather brings them into the limelight, albeit briefly and thus into question. 
The story is simple enough, the gameplay is linear and straightforward. The voice acting is well done and the environments are also well done and ~mostly~ lovely to look at (The entire town tends to be a bit depressive so some things aren't visually appealing and are meant to be that way) Achievements are not really hard to come by if you're someone who likes to 100% a game.

I would suggest buying the game on sale however, as it is rather short and the 22+ CAD price tag is a little steep for the playtime (I've played just over 5 hours and managed all the achievements)

Overall, definitely worth picking up on sale and worth a playthrough and will most likely end up tugging at your heartstrings a bit.

118644841.review:
I have really mixed feelings on this one. Liked the art and atmosphere. Animated parts were funny and well-done. Story was interesting especially in retrospect. Mostly because of the ending. The other "plot twist" is pretty obvious relatively early in the game and foreshadowing for it kind of misses it mark. I liked the fox, even though he didn´t do much during most of the game. I guess the main villain was also ok. Didn´t mind the music. 

Everything else I pretty much hated. The main character voice-acting is just puzzling. I have no idea what they where going for, but it just doesn´t work. Dialogue clearly tries to be witty, but is mostly flat, boring and inconsequential. There also isn´t much to play. Basically you just walk forward and hit any action points while doing it. Only directions you can move are left and right, but mostly you just need to move in one direction. There isn´t really anything that requires much thinking and the game could basically play itself.

Tonally the game is all over the place. You get very serious adult themes like suicide, alcoholism, parental neglect, missing/dead children and next there are poop jokes and slapstick humor. I think the idea was to portray adult themes through innocent child´s perspective, but it just doesn´t work very well.

Can´t really recommend this as a game. Playtime is only 2-3 hours so if you get it cheap and need to kill some time, I would  recommend it just for the art and story.

Yikes forever.

118351707.review:
Me encantó este juego, la historia es increíble y creativa, si bien tiene un estilo visual adorable, no te dejes engañar porque el juego está lleno de momentos perturbadores, diálogos turbios y subidos de tono, la jugabilidad es simple y sin puzzles complejos, aún así te mantiene en una atmósfera tensa y de suspenso.
Además es muy reflexivo, porque tomas bastantes decisiones a lo largo del transcurso, que ponen en jaque lo que está "bien" y lo que está "mal", en realidad sólo son acciones que tienen consecuencias, en resumidas cuentas y como dice la frase: “Lo Esencial es Invisible a los Ojos”. Lo recomiendo 100% <3

118315938.review:
This game is short but an incredible ride as it leads you through an unfortunate day in the life of little Misfortune. I found myself entranced all the while, and it made me cry like a baby at the end. I went back to get the true ending as well, and I /still/ wound up crying all over again. 

It's freaky and fun and delightfully animated. If you have a few hours to spare, I recommend playing this game all in one go.

118291967.review:
Primero debo decir que me encanta Fran Bow (El primer y anterior juego de Killmonday Games), soy un fanático de su creadora Natalia Martinsson y estaré ahí el día 1 para cuando salga su nuevo juego y el DLC de Fran Bow.

Dejando lo anterior de lado, tengo un top con los 3 peores juegos que he jugado en mi vida y Little Misfortune está en ese top. 

Este juego es terrible, no se me ocurre nada bueno sobre él. No me trajo nada más que aburrimiento. Detesto el voice acting, es como un rechinido. El humor no da risa. El guión no es interesante. Tiene una mecánica en que deja claro que el jugador y la protagonista son dos personajes distintos dentro del juego y desconecta demasiado a la hora de jugar y en ciertos momentos específicos. Hay como 2 minijuegos y 1 puzzle y son basiquísimos. (en comparación a fran bow que eran complejos y divertidos). La música es meh, lo cual es una pena porque en Fran Bow de verdad aportaba. En términos artísticos todos los escenarios se ven demasiado parecidos. Para un juego con fuerzas sobrenaturales, todo es demasiado mundano.

No recomiendo este juego en absoluto.

118204879.review:
This is a lovely little game that balances nicely between being sweet and ominous. Much more lighthearted than Fran Bow (as main character is an adorably naive 8yo kiddo) but still has a lot of dark themes. It´s very story driven, so expect a lot of dialogue :) The choices you make (option A or B) affect the story a little bit, but I´d say the endings I´ve gotten are quite similar. 
Still; it was very enjoyable (I replayed it a few times) with an interesting story, an art style that fit the tone perfectly and a nice change of pace as compared to Fran Bow

BIG BONUSES: could pet animals, throw glitter everywhere and eat floor candy, 10/10
